journeys.title: What is Time?
journeys.description: A journey from everyday experience to the edge of physics and consciousness

questions.main: Why does time only move forward?
questions.context: You can walk backwards in space, but not in time. Why this fundamental asymmetry?
questions.followUp: Is the arrow of time a law of physics or just how we experience it?

questions.main: Is time absolute or relative?
questions.context: Newton believed in universal time ticking everywhere. Einstein destroyed this idea. Your head ages faster than your feet.
questions.followUp: If time is relative, is there a 'now' that exists across the universe?

questions.main: What exactly is 'now'?
questions.context: The present moment seems special, but physics can't find it. The equations work equally well backwards.
questions.followUp: How long does 'now' last? A second? A nanosecond? An instant?

questions.main: Does time exist without change?
questions.context: Imagine a universe where nothing moves, nothing changes. Would time still pass? Or does time require events?
questions.followUp: Are you measuring time, or are you measuring change and calling it time?

questions.main: Is the past still real?
questions.context: Einstein's block universe suggests all moments exist eternally. Your childhood is still happening 'somewhere' in spacetime.
questions.followUp: If all moments exist equally, why do we only experience this one?

questions.main: Can you think about time without using time?
questions.context: Augustine realized that to think about the past requires present memory, to think about future requires present expectation. All time exists only in the present mind.
questions.followUp: Is time a feature of consciousness rather than reality?

questions.main: Is time in the world or in your mind?
questions.context: Kant argued time is a necessary form of perception - not a thing in itself but how minds must experience reality. Without minds, no time.
questions.followUp: Could an alien consciousness experience reality without temporal sequence?

questions.main: Does observation create the flow of time?
questions.context: In quantum mechanics, observation collapses possibilities into actualities. Does consciousness create the 'now' by observing?
questions.followUp: Is time emerging from quantum decoherence?

questions.main: Can time go backwards at quantum scales?
questions.context: Quantum equations are time-symmetric. Particles seem to 'know' about future measurements. Retrocausation might be real.
questions.followUp: If microscopic time is reversible, why is macroscopic time not?

questions.main: Did time have a beginning?
questions.context: If time started at the Big Bang, what does 'before' even mean? Can something cause time to begin if causation requires time?
questions.followUp: Is asking 'what came before time' like asking 'what's north of the North Pole'?

questions.main: Is time fundamental or emergent?
questions.context: Some physicists think time emerges from more basic timeless processes - like temperature emerges from molecular motion. Time might not be real at the deepest level.
questions.followUp: What would a timeless reality 'beneath' time look like?

questions.main: Why do you experience 'now' as special?
questions.context: Physics says all moments are equal, yet you're trapped in this one. Why this moment? Why you? Why now?
questions.followUp: Is your entire life happening in one eternal moment that you're experiencing sequentially?

journeys.title: Does God Exist?
journeys.description: A journey from childhood certainty through doubt to the edge of the knowable

questions.main: Who created everything?
questions.context: Every child asks this. Everything seems to need a cause. Your parents made you, but who made the first parents?
questions.followUp: If God created everything, who created God?

questions.main: Can something come from nothing?
questions.context: Aquinas argued that existence itself needs explanation. Why is there something rather than nothing at all?
questions.followUp: Is 'nothing' even possible, or is 'something' necessary?

questions.main: Does the universe's design imply a designer?
questions.context: The constants of physics are fine-tuned for life to 120 decimal places. Change gravity by 0.0000...1% and no atoms form.
questions.followUp: Is fine-tuning evidence of God, or are we in one of infinite universes?

questions.main: Why doesn't God provide proof?
questions.context: An omnipotent God could easily prove existence - write in the stars, appear to everyone simultaneously. Why the hiddenness?
questions.followUp: Would proof of God eliminate free will to believe?

questions.main: Can absence of evidence be evidence of absence?
questions.context: Bertrand Russell's teapot: You can't disprove a teapot orbiting Mars. Does that make it reasonable to believe?
questions.followUp: Is God more like a teapot or like consciousness - unprovable but undeniable?

journeys.title: What is Consciousness?
journeys.description: A journey from the obvious to the impossible

questions.main: How do you know you're conscious?
questions.context: You can doubt everything except that you're experiencing doubt. Consciousness is the only thing you know directly.
questions.followUp: Could you be conscious but wrong about what consciousness is?

questions.main: Why does it feel like something to be you?
questions.context: Computers process information without feeling. Why does your brain processing create inner experience?
questions.followUp: Is feeling separate from processing, or identical to it?

questions.main: Could a perfect copy of your brain be conscious?
questions.context: If we replicated every neuron, every connection, every chemical - would it experience being 'someone'?
questions.followUp: Would it be you, another you, or someone else entirely?
